data.title: Greatest album that Jeff Porcaro was associated with
data.text:
Umm. no. Its not just based on sales... its based on the huge impact it had on the United States and even the world. On society, on culture, on race relations..

As a 11/12 year old white kid at the time of Thriller's release I can tell you that Michael Jackson (and the Cosby show subsequently) did more to foster a color blind attitude to people than just about anything else. I think we take that attitude for granted these days but it was not always so. And for about a year or two during Thriller's reign Michael Jackson was IT.

Thriller did not sell 30 million copies in the US because people bought it even though it was crap.. its a masterpiece, partly, because of the great musicians, including Porcaro and of course Quincy Jones, that helped Michael Jackson create it.

You can't compare the seminal moment that was Thriller to anything else. A complete quality product from beginning to end including of course the John Landis video.

I did not vote since many great albums were left out:

Seals & Crofts - Unborn Child (1974)

Tommy Bolin - Teaser (1975) - tracks 1, 2, 3, 5

Steely Dan - Pretzel Logic (1974), Gaucho (1980)

Boz Scaggs - Down Two Then Left (1977), Middle Man (1980), Other Roads (1988)

Hall & Oates - Beauty on a Back Street (1977)

Larry Carlton - Room 335 Album (1978)

Warren Zevon - Excitable Boy (1978) - "Nighttime in the Switching Yard"

Colin Blunstone - Never Even Thought (1978)

Lowell George - Thanks, I'll Eat It Here (1979)

Pink Floyd - The Wall - "Mother"

Bee Gees - Living Eyes (1981)

Greg Lake - Greg Lake (1981)

Michael Jackson - Dangerous (1991) - "Beat It", "Human Nature", "The Girl is Mine", "The Lady in my Life", "Heal the World"

Elton John - Jump Up!

Don Henley - I Can't Stand Still (1982)

Christopher Cross - Another Page (1983)

James Newton Howard - "James Newton Howard and Friends" (1983)

Michael McDonald - If That's What It Takes (1982) - No Lookin' Back (1985) - "Take It To Heart" (1990)

Eric Clapton - Behind the Sun (1985) - Forever Man

Jon Anderson - In the City of Angels (1988)

Clair Marlo - Let It Go (1989)

Madonna - Like a Prayer (1989)

Twenty Mondays - The Twist Inside (1990)

Michael Bolton - Time, Love & Tenderness (1991)

Cher - Love Hurts (1991)

Dire Straits - On Every Street (1991)

Bruce Springsteen - Human Touch (1992)

Christopher Cross - Rendezvous (1992)

10cc - ...Meanwhile (1992)

THIS

And im a HUGE Steely Dan fan. I own all of their albums. Thriller was a landmark, it wasn't some passing fad like Vanilla Ice or Milli Vanilli. It was acclaimed because it was a benchmark of music. You have the legendary Quincy Jones, MJ: one of the greatest artist in his absolute prime who was singing like his head was about to explode and the greatest collection of writers and studio musicians ever assembled. Eddie Van Halen, Louis Johnson, Toto, Greg Philliganes, Janet Jackson, Michael Boddicker, Macca!!

Perhaps the OP should have worded his question a bit differently, like "Your favorite album Jeff Procaro was associated with", because, otherwise, there's just no point in doing the poll. There is no debate on "Thriller" being the "greatest" in terms of sales and popularity. Period.
